review.title: Graphical Models for Game Theory
review.abstract: In this work, we introduce graphical modelsfor multi-player game theory, and give powerful algorithms for computing their Nash equilibria in certain cases. An n-player game is given by an undirected graph on n nodes and a set of n local matrices. The interpretation is that the payoff to player i is determined entirely by the actions of player i and his neighbors in the graph, and thus the payoff matrix to player i is indexed only by these players i.e., the payoff matrix to player i is determined by the relative sums of the total sum of the total sum of those who will be in the real world (in addition to the sums of the total sum of those who will be in the real world) and the value of the total sum of the total sum of the total sum of those who will be in the real world. metadata.title: Graphical Models for Game Theory
metadata.abstractText: We introduce a compact graph-theoretic repre­ sentation for multi-party game theory. Our main result is a provably correct and efficient algo­ rithm for computing approximate Nash equilibria in one-stage games represented by trees or sparse graphs.
